bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.H. Brooke, June 2, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests permission to look at telegrams sent and received by the Surgeon General's office between 1900 and 1901.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.H. Brooke, June 2, 1941
div1.opener:
Y F.
June 2, 1941
Mr. H. R. Brooke
Chief Clerk of the Surgeon General's office
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Brooke:
div1.p:
About three weeks ago, ex-Surgeon General Ireland and Brigadier General
Kean were kind enough to help me in Washington, trying to locate some of the historical
records pertaining to Walter Reed and his colleagues done at the Post Hospital at
Camp Columbia, Quemados (Havana) Cuba in 1900 and 1901. Generals Ireland and Kean
kindly took me personally to the Archives Building and then over to the Army College
where I found much interesting material. Mr. P. M. Hamer, Chief of the Division of
Reference at the Archives, informs me that the telegrams sent and received by the
Surgeon General's office between 1900 and 1901 are on file in Fort Myer, Virginia.
I am very anxious to consult those telegrams, that is, those which were sent to and
from Walter Reed, Lazear, Carroll and Agramonte, to and from the Surgeon General.
Only a few of these telegrams have been published but I am anxious to study then
in connection with some research work which I have been carrying on with the conquest
of yellow fever.

Last year, I gave an address on this conquest on the occasion of the
dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson College.
This week I am giving the principal address at the unveiling of Dean Cornwell's
new painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”. In this research I have been greatly
indebted to General Ireland, General Kean, General Truby and many others who were
close to this work.

If you will tell me how I can get permission to study these telegrams, I
will appreciate it greatly. I should either like to see them the next time I come
to Washington (and would be willing to spend some time looking them over) or, if
this were possible, I should be perfectly willing to pay some clerk to copy for me
all the telegrams pertaining to the work of the yellow fever work, signed either by
General Sternberg or his associates or by any members of the United States Yellow
Fever Board, providing this isn't too expensive.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
(Signed in Dr. Hench's absence)
